summary.seg: The Cambridge University Library bestiary is among the best known of English bestiaries, largely due to it being the subject of M.R. James's 1928 facsimile, whose commentary laid the groundwork in listing and grouping many other bestiary texts. Also, the 1954 book by T.H. White provided an English translation of its texts, accompanied by its illustrations, so knowledge of this manuscript reached a wide popular audience.

Some pages have been excised, and these perhaps contained illustrations of the antelope, unicorn, the first scene of the story of the dog and the murder of his master, 'Adam Naming the Animals', and three birds (perhaps the raven, crow and dove). The iconography of the creatures and birds in several cases is quite close to the Worksop bestiary (New York, Morgan Library and Museum, MS M.81) and the St Petersburg bestiary (St Petersburg, National Library of Russia, MS Q.v.V.1), although there are difference in their order of the texts. The Cambridge bestiary more closely compares with the order of texts and iconography of the Aberdeen and Ashmole bestiaries (Aberdeen, University Library, MS 24 and Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 1511), although unlike them it does not contain either the Creation scenes from Genesis at the beginning or Hugh of Fouilloy's aviary with its accompanying pictures. This explains why the maximum number of pictures it contained, 107, is much less than the 131 in the Ashmole bestiary.

Otherwise, the text is relatively close to that of the Ashmole bestiary, both similar to a bestiary of c. 1170 (London, British Library, MS Add. 11283), which seems to be the earliest manuscript to have more or less the same order of texts. A notable difference from Ashmole is the placing of 'Adam Naming the Animals' between the scenes concerning dogs and the account of the sheep, whereas Ashmole places the Adam scene at the beginning before the account of the lion. The leaf with the Adam scene has been excised from the Cambridge manuscript, but the missing leaf is between the scenes of the habits of dogs and that of the sheep. This placing of the Adam scene also occurs in two bestiaries of the second quarter of the thirteenth century: London, British Library, Royal MS 12 F. xiii and Harley MS 3244.

The Cambridge bestiary is unusual in that its first few pictures - the two full pages of the lion and the tiger, the pard, the panther, and the lynx - are fully painted, whereas from then on, starting with the griffin, penwork drawings are used. These seem to be deliberately and carefully finished in ink, presumably over preliminary outlines in plummet. A few have pale colour washes that do not suppress the ink drawing lines, but the majority are without such washes. It is indeed fortunate that an artist did not paint over these drawings because they are by a draughtsman of outstanding ability, superior to the less able painter who worked on the first six illustrations, who would probably have ruined these splendid drawings if he had painted over them.

The style of these drawings is linked to those in the Guthlac Roll (London, British Library, Harley Roll Y.6), probably made for the Benedictine Abbey of Crowland, Lincolnshire, c. 1210-20. Both the Cambridge bestiary and the Guthlac Roll are stylistically related to some of the stained glass in Lincoln Cathedral of the first quarter of the thirteenth century. These connections of the style of drawings with places in Lincolnshire and the possible ownership of the bestiary by Revesby Abbey, albeit rather speculative, make it likely that the book was made in that region, or possibly in Yorkshire, the county to the north of Lincolnshire. Also, the closeness of the iconography to some of the bestiary images in the Worksop bestiary supports location in this region. Worksop is in Nottinghamshire, the county adjacent Lincolnshire, which was part of the archdiocese of York. A possible centre of production is the city of Lincoln, and some have suggested that the scholar William de Montibus (d. 1213), master of the cathedral school from the late 1180s and from 1194 chancellor of the cathedral, may have had a role in establishing or influencing the text content of the Worksop, Cambridge, and other bestiaries. The Distinctiones theologicae ('Theological distinctions') and Numerale (Numeral) of William de Montibus influenced the texts of some manuscripts of a defined group of bestiaries, including Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum, MS 254.

Perhaps the Latin bestiaries were primarily read by priests and men in the religious orders. Several belonged to religious houses or to individual Benedictines, Cistercians, Augustinian canons, Dominicans or Franciscans. The bestiary may have been more widely read by them than by members of the laity, for whose ownership, particularly of Latin bestiaries, there is less evidence. Bestiaries in the vernacular languages of Anglo-Norman, those of Philippe de Thaon and Guillaume le Clerc, and in Middle English were probably intended mainly for reading by lay men and women. However, it should be pointed out that many fewer English manuscripts survive of the vernacular versions than do those of the Latin texts.
Professor Nigel Morgan, Emeritus Honorary Professor of the History of Art, University of Cambridge

msItem.title: Bestiary
msItem.incipit: 2r: Leo fortissimus besitarum ad nullius pauebit occursum
msItem.filiation: For full discussion of the iconographic and textual relationship between this and other bestiaries and other manuscripts, see the introductory summary.

extent.seg: 4 leaves of parchment have been inserted in place of missing leaves, when the volume was rebound (for further information on which, see Foliation and Binding). These inserted leaves have been digitised but have not been counted here as part of the manuscript's extent. For the sake of clarity, it has been decided not to enumerate them separately either. iv + 74 + iii leaves.

note.p: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, partly by an unidentified hand of the 20th century (probably first half) (21, 31, 41, etc only), with the leaves in between being numbered later by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..
Folios [5a], [19a], [21a] and [40a] are post-medieval parchment leaves inserted in place of missing leaves in order to ensure the stability of the remaining half of the bifolia.

list.item: Quire 38-2 (ff. 16-21: 5th leaf, after f. 19, and 8th leaf, after f. 21, missing)
Quire 108-2 (ff. 69-74: 7th and 8th leaves, after f. 74, missing)

signatures.p: Quire signatures, in Roman numerals, written in plummet in the lower margin of the recto side of the first leaf of the quire.

Leaf signatures has been written in plummet in the lower margin of the recto sides of the leaves in the first half of the quire, after the first leaf (from Quire 2 onwards). These continue the numerical sequence begun by the quire number: so, in Quire 4 for example, the first leaf is 'iv', the second 'v', the third 'vi' and the fourth 'vii'; in Quire 5, the first is 'v', the second 'vi', the third 'vii' and the fourth 'viii'; etc.

layout.seg: Pricked in the outer margins; usually mostly trimmed.

Ruled in plummet. Pattern variable: generally, single vertical bounding lines extending the full length of the page; first and second horizontal lines extending the full width of the page; penultimate and last horizontal lines extending into the margin and occasionally the full width of the page.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in Caroline minuscule.

list.item: 1r-1v: two full-page miniatures, in colours, containing three horizontal registers and illustrating aspects of a lion's nature
3v: 1/3-page miniature, illustrating in two vertical registers, showing a tiger on the left and a man on horseback holding a sword and whelp on the right

decoDesc.decoNote:
Drawings of various sizes in circular or rectangular frames, very few partly or fully tinted:
4r: leopard (fully tinted)
4v: panther attracting animals with its sweet breath (fully tinted)
4v: panther attracting animals with its sweet breath (fully tinted)
6r: lynx (fully tinted)
6v: griffin snatching a pig
7r: elephant carrying four armed men and led by a man with a scourge
8v: beaver and three hunters
9r: ibex falling downhill; hyena devouring corpse
10r: bonnacon and three hunters
10v: six apes
11r: satyr; stag
12r: goat
13r: two wild goats
13v: monoceros; bear
14v: leucrota
15r: crocodile devouring a man
15v: manticore
16r: parandrus; fox tricking birds by pretending to be dead (partly tinted)
16v: yale
17r: wolf approaching domestic animals in a stable
18v: three dogs
19r: in two horizontal registers: King Garamantes in capitivity, and being saved by his dogs
20r: in three horizontal registers: dogs
22r: sheep; ram
22v: lamb; he-goat
23r: two wild boars; bullock
23v: ox
24r: camel
24v: dromedary
25r: donkey; wild ass
25v: horse
28r: three cats, one with a mouse in its paws; mouse; weasel
28v: mole; six headgehogs underneath stylised (?fruit-)bush of interlaced foliage
29r: ants, represented by ant-hills
31r: three eagles: one ascending, carrying a fish; a second approaching the sun; a third, falling down
32r: two vultures, perched on a stylised bush of interlacing foliage
32v: five cranes, one holding aloft an egg in its claw
33r: parrot
33v: caladrius perched on bedsheets, a man in bed asleep (partly tinted)
34r: stork eating a frog
34v: swan eating a fish; ibis snatching a snake and feeding its three young in a nest
35r: two ostriches: one looking up at the sun, the other holding in its beak an egg on the ground
35v: coot
36r: halcyon; phoenix pecking at the leaves of a bush
36v: phoenix in nest surrounded by fire
37v: cinnamolgus with young in nest atop a tree, two men below hunting with slings; ercinea
38r: hoopoe with young pecking at its beak and plumage; pelicans
38v: owl
39r: siren holding a fish
39v: two patridges preening one another's feathers; patridge with a nest of eggs
40r: magpie; hawk
40v: nightingale nesting; bat
41r: two turtledoves perched on a bush
41v: swallow
42v: quail; peacock; hoopoe; cockerel
43r: three ducks
43v: beehive (bees added with caption 'apes', s. xv)
45v: perindeus tree with doves in its branches and below two dragons, mouths open, doves feeding from between their teeth
46v: dragon attacking an elephant
47r: basilisk
47v: viper
48v: asp being struck with a stick by a man holding a shield
49v: scitalis; amphisbaena; hydrus
50r: three boas
50v: jaculus; siren-serpent; lizard
51r: six salamanders entwined in the branches of a tree with a man asleep on the ground beneath
51v: saura; stellio
52r: snake shedding its skin in the form of a dragon squeezing through a tower
54r: fish and various sea creatures
54v: whale attacking men in a boat
63v: Isidore of Seville seated and writing at a desk

decoNote.p: Green, red or blue initials (2-7 lines) with blue or red penwork infill and flourishing, occasionally elaborate, at the beginning of each description.
Similar, but smaller, initials also occur, the same colours, but without flourishing

binding.p: Quarter tawed pigskin with oak boards, two clasps. On the outside, skin tooled with interlaced foliage pattern, inhabited by pairs of birds, arising from the raised bands. Douglas Cockerell and SonDouglas Cockerell and Son (Firm), Letchworth, 1928 (stamp on skin on inside of right-hand board).
Formerly bound in paper boards (according to unpublished description of the manuscript by M.R. James; see Source for further details).

provenance.p: 73r: 'Iacobus Thomas Herison Thys ys ye Abbaye of Rev-', cropped inscription, suggesting the manuscript was perhaps at the Cistercian abbey of Revesby, LincolnshireRevesby Abbey (England), by the 16th century. However, this ownership was rejected by N.R. Ker, Medieval Libraries of Great Britain, 2nd edn. (1964), p. 158.

history.acquisition: Given to the University Library on 16 July 1655 by Osbert Fowler, registrar of King's College, Cambridge 1641-58 (inscription on f. ii verso, by the hand of Jonathan Pindar (fl. 1652-1664)Pindar, Jonathan (fl. 1652-1664), Under Library-Keeper).

recordHist.source:
This catalogue entry draws on:
the description provided by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011) (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press)
an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74) The introductory summary is taken from the catalogue entry for the 2019 exhibition Book of Beasts: The Bestiary in the Medieval World, ed. by Elizabeth Morrison with Larisa Grollemond.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
